title: Do Christians believe in science? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am a Christian. And I rely on science to inform me on the material world (which possibly is the only world there is). But forget the Christianity part. Just classify me as a “believer.” I believe god exists. There you go: flat out and ugly; I believe. Christianity is just the fine tuning; that’s how I believe, how I connect. Everyone on board, here? Good. Now, do I BELIEVE in science? ABSOLUTELY NOT. Science is not to be believed, and the reaction of scientists to people who DO believe in science would range from suspicion to abject horror. The deal with science is that anything that is proposed as true cannot be so proposed unless it is subject to test in accordance with methods and procedures upon which scientists are in general agreement. That is, the results of any theory or proposition must be repeated by others; if they can’t be, the theory looks weak. Need more tests. And if the results are upheld, then they STILL must be tested by others. Prove it, prove it again, and then prove it again. That’s not belief. That’s an actual demonstration. And once anything has been proved enough times, it becomes a “theory.” That is, something which is tentatively accepted as true until shown to be otherwise. The “acceptance” may carry with it the weight of great evidence. Even so, there is no “sure thing.” Everything is open to question, doubt and change. THAT’S how science works. Bottom-line: science is not based on belief, OK? Now, the Bible. Applying my scientific mind, to it, I realize immediately that it is not a scientific work. It is, rather, a collection of independently written stories, myths, reports and opinions from many writers who were widely separated by geography and time, and who did not know each other and none of whom knew all their work would one day be assembled in a single work which people centuries or decades after their time would call a “Bible.” No science here, folks. And probably not much belief, either. There are so many contradictions in the Bible that it is, in my opinion, impossible to believe in all of it. It is, however, possible to be INFORMED by it, and draw from the text such guidance as we may apply to our own lives. If I gave you a stack of newspaper written during the US Civil War, you would notice a bias based on where the papers were written, and who wrote the articles. And you would evaluate all this in accordance with how much you knew, or thought you knew, about everything else. But you would not reasonably form a belief on any of it. If you HAD a belief, it would be informed by more sources other than the newspapers. So, to answer the question at hand, as a Christian, I neither believe in science, nor the Bible. I look at everything, and make up my own mind. Hope that helps.

Do Christians believe in science? Of course they do. Every technology used by us to ease our lives is the proof that science is true. However please note that human science is not final yet. What was thought to be legit once, might not be so later on, when new discovery comes up. For example, once Pluto was deemed to be the ninth planet. But now, not anymore. Once Milky-Way thought to be the center of universe and the only one, but now there are so many galaxies, and each galaxy has so many stars, that scientists compared the stars as many as the sand of beach. Interestingly, the Bible come up with similar comparison: “I will surely bless you, and I will surely multiply your offspring as the stars of heaven and as the sand that is on the seashore. And your offspring shall possess the gate of his enemies.”—Genesis 22:17 (ESV) Please note that the Bible writer of this account lived about 3,500 years ago. There was no telescope at that time. The number of stars seen with naked eyes are only about 3,000 - 5,000 only. So, how did the writer know this fact? Once people believed in abiogenesis or generatio spontania (that life emerges by itself from anorganic matters), but Louis Pasteur gave a lethal blow to that theory, and scientists followed him and believed in biogenesis (that life emerges from previous life). And now, some scientists want us to believe in a new-face of abiogenesis called evolution. These are not the only examples. There are so many human-shifting theories. So you see that human science keeps changing. Why do we defend on the theory that keeps changing? We can hold to the provable theory and science, but we should not do that on an unproven theory and human-shifting science.

To christians: If you believe in science, how can you also believe in The Bible? …science states that the earth is 2.5 billion years old, while The Bible states it is 4,000… A2A. Your assertion is in error. The Bible does not “state that the world is 4,000 years old.” There have been some Bible scholars who have interpolated what the Bible DOES say, using genealogies and such, to calculate the age of the earth. Most of these estimates have put the age of the earth at somewhere between 6,000 and 10,000 years. That’s still a wide disparity with 2.5 billion, but not all Christians believe in this view (called “Young Earth Creationism”). In fact, the majority of Christians do not. Even some who do, explain it by saying that Adam, the first man, was created as a young man, not an infant. So if God can create a man with an apparent age of, say, 25, why could he not create a universe already in progress, including an earth with an apparent age? I do not necessarily agree with this line of reasoning, but it’s one way those who do can reconcile science and the Bible. More Christians believe in Old Earth Creationism, which includes the view that evolution is one of the mechanisms the Creator God built into the universe. To “believe in the Bible” does not require suspension of scientific belief. It only requires a degree of interpretation of some passages as more literal than others. This is the same way pretty much all readers evaluate all literature. For example, when a news report says “The whole town came out to greet their winning team,” this is called “hyperbole.” We do not generally take that to mean every single human in that town. We take it to mean “a lot of people.” The fact that there is some disagreement among Christians regarding some passages which may be interpreted as hyperbole, parable, or any other literary device, does not mean that all Christians cannot “believe in the Bible” and still believe in science.

Questions similar to this have come up elsewhere on this site, so I’m just reproducing an answer I gave to a similar question elsewhere on this site. Remember first of all that the Bible is actually a collection of dozens of books that were written (if you accept the concept of Divine Inspiration, then say “collaborated on”) over many centuries for many reasons. Even the three synoptic Gospels were written for different audiences to grind a different ax. So, let me ask you, do you take a library literally? Of course not. If you’re reading Harry Potter or The Lord of the Rings Trilogy, you know you’re reading fantasy, that there are really no such things as wizards, and elves, and hobbits, etc. If you’re reading fiction that is based more on technical accuracy, like a police procedural or a novelized account of the Battle of Gettysburg such as Shaara’s The Killer Angels, or the French Reign of Terror such as Dickens’s A Tale of Two Cities, you’ll still know that it’s fiction, but you might have faith in the underlying technical details. If you read a biography, or a history, or a journalistic account of a crime, you might take those literally, because they’re meant to be taken literally. Doesn’t mean mistakes don’t get made. That’s why the details in one account of the Battle of Leyte Gulf might be different from the details in a different account. In the Bible, you’ll find historical accounts of the early days of the Hebrews, and the Hebrew peoples’ evolution from a society ruled by a group of Judges to a Monarchy. You’ll also find fantasy stories that give a lesson, like the Book of Job. You’ll also find collections of prayers for almost any occasion, as in Psalms. You’ll also find biographies, like the Gospels, sermons, like the Epistles of St. Paul, an erotic romantic poem called the Canticle of Canticles (or the Song of Solomon), and all kinds of other books. In each case you have to put the individual book, and the individual chapter and verse in context. For example, is God literally a shepherd, or is that a metaphor to help us understand how He cares for us? Is God literally a King, or is that a metaphor to help us understand His great power? Is God literally a vine and all of us branches, or is that a metaphor to help us understand our interconnectedness with God and with each other? And, if science, which God is also the author of, seems to indicate that parts of the Bible that were once routinely taken literally are not literally true, then maybe, with our improved scientific understanding, we can come to view those passages metaphorically. If the Bible is Divinely Inspired, it can’t be wrong. And if God is the Creator of all things, nature and science can’t be wrong. Therefore, if there seems to be a conflict between Science and Scripture, then it is our understanding of either Scripture or Science that’s in error. Not God’s Word. And not His Works.

Science is exceedingly important to me. Science is one of my passions and was foundational to my career for 35 years. My Bachelor's and Master's degrees are in engineering but most courses were science. Science has contributed immeasurably to my comfort, security, leisure and education. Science brought my ancestors out of the stone age. I love learning about science and always have. And science helps shape my world-view. When I find a well-substantiated scientific observation that conflicts with what I believe, I need to change one or the other. If the new science is documented well enough, I will change my world-view, including religious beliefs. But so far, I have never heard any science that conflicts with the most basic premises of the Christian faith, including the inspired Bible. Science does not conflict with the Bible, unless you take the Bible as 100% literal. Then you have a problem, particularly in the numerous places where the Bible contradicts itself. But I believe that some of the Bible is literal history and some is metaphor. However, the Bible is not primarily a science book, it was written to teach people how to relate to God. So for instance, the parables told by Jesus were intentionally fiction, and the value of them lays in their moral. The books of Job, Daniel and Revelation are also highly allegorical - they teach important truths whether or not the actual events happened (or will happen) as reported.

Not all do. Some Christians take a simplistic “blind faith” approach to their spirituality. However, I am a Christian and I believe in science. I believe in chemistry. I believe in physics. I believe in evolution. I believe that everything God does is within the physical laws of the universe. The main difference between us and Him (which is also the reason so many choose to disbelieve God or science) is because he understands those laws perfectly and we don't. “But the Creation?” you ask? God's six-day creation is symbolic of six divisions of time, each one taking perhaps millions or even billions of years. When you are an eternal being, what does a day even mean? Maybe his day is much, much longer than ours. “What about Christ's miracles?” They're only miracles to us, because we don't understand the physical laws employed. Bring anyone from the 15th century into our world today and they will witness miracles all around them as well: cell phones, televisions, automobiles, airplanes, electric light! All pretty darn miraculous to that person. As long as you study the scriptures, pray, and seek guidance from the Holy Ghost, God can give you answers to your questions and concerns.

Most of us say we do. A quick visit to the Creation Museum in Kentucky, however, taught me that some don’t understand science, and may not understand faith. Science means looking at the evidence and forming a theory based on that evidence. If new evidence makes the previous theory untenable, one changes the theory. Discoveries that challenge accepted wisdom are welcomed because they lead to greater knowledge and understanding. Picking and choosing “evidence” to support your beliefs while ignoring anything that contradicts it, while calling it science (as many “Christians” do), is simply fraud. Faith is belief in something that can not be proved, because the creator is always greater than the created. An example of faith is believing that God created everything. It is not antithetical to science, which only shows the person of faith deeper knowledge of how God created everything, thus giving a deeper awareness of the incomprehensible mystery we call God. This kind of faith views science as a tool of faith, not an enemy. For some of us, science deepens faith. For others, science challenges faith. Personally I think a faith that requires its believer to deny reality is at best delusion, and at worst spiritual abuse.

Of course! The Bible is perfectly scientific and accurate. Isaiah 40:22 tells us that the earth is a sphere and that the universe is expanding. This verse was written during the Bronze Age, not the most scientific of times. Yet, this verse is completely accurate. Indeed, the universe has been discovered to be expanding, and, as we all know, the earth is indeed a sphere. I doubt that whoever write that verse would have unless he or she had imperial proof it was so. The only imperial proof would be being told by God. Suggesting this was so without being told so by God is out I the question. Suggesting so would have brought mockery and ridicule upon whoever dared claimed so. There is no reason to claim so other than being told by God. In Genesis, the Bible talks about underwater valcanos. How does anybody in the Bronze Age know about that? Being told by God only makes sence. Christians have every reason to believe science, and do.

Yes. I believe so. It’s quite simple. God created universe. There was method in the madness. The sheer vastness, unbridgeable distances, unimaginable long times, incredible temperatures and densities, everything was against the possibility of any kind of biological life, which is generally quite fragile, to exist. Yet it does. Maybe only in one little spot in the whole wide universe: a tiny, humble planet called earth. Where conditions are exactly, precisely right to make it possible. And only just. Everybody’s life constantly seem to hang by a thread. It’s the precision in nature that makes science possible. There are enough patterns, rules, or laws in nature. There is something in nature making it predictable and understandable to some extent. It can be described as follows: every system acts according to its nature. That nature is inherent to all systems. Even chaotic systems have a nature. What makes science possible: if you know the nature of a system, you can predict it’s behaviour (like farmers and fishermen learned to predict weather - their lives depended on it). If you don’t know it’s nature, you can study it’s behaviour, and from that make hypotheses about its nature, which you use to make testable predictions, which you check in systems behaviour, which you use to adjust hypotheses to better fit reality, until it becomes as good as general relativity or quantum physics in describing and predicting behaviours. There you have it: the scientific method - based on systems, their nature and their behaviour. Science is about observation, measurements and reasoning. Science observed the magnificence of God’s works and described it in an objective way. Thus it is. Things are this way, not another way. It has certain very specific characteristics. It could have had any number of possible different characteristics. But it is as it is. That’s the reality we have to deal with. Genesis states that God created everything according to their nature, or kind. It is this nature that makes science possible. I believe all of the above to be true. This believe is not the same as my belief in God of the Bible. My belief in science is the conclusion that on the balance evidence indicates that the scientific conclusion (not consensus - that’s popular vote) is the best explanation available, currently. It’s by no means permanent or perfect. It stands to be corrected, as soon as new evidence becomes available. Scientific conclusion are essentially temporal, always waiting to be refuted, or confirmed by new evidence. God, on the other hand, is not subject to such faith. He needs no evidence. He is evidence itself. I believe God on his authority. I don’t believe scientific journals because they have any authority. I read what’s in it, and judge for myself. It’s like a poker player putting his cards on the table- they speak for themselves (I borrowed this idea from another Quora writer - W. Hoffmann). You put your hypothesis on the table. Other scientists investigate it and pronounce it dead or alive. We never say something is so because it’s in science books. We see for ourselves. Seeing is believing. When it comes to God believing is seeing. You have to believe before you see. Is it possible to hold such conflicting ideas in one brain? Why not? We can’t function without belief. Most beliefs are implicit, hidden in our behaviour. We drive cars at 120 km/h on one side of the road while other cars are being hurled our way at the same speed from the opposite side. We pass each other by a few centimeters. We do it calmly, matter of factly, as if it’s nothing. We assume the other driver will act rationally, predictably and reasonably. One mistake and oblivion. How do we do that? Faith, brother, faith. We trust all the science behind it. So why shouldn’t I trust God? Trusting behaviours of cars and drivers on highways seem more like wishful thinking than faith to me.

Most Christians accept science to one degree or another. After all, most will drive cars, use electricity, see a doctor, and they do not believe that any of these things are magical or God-powered devices. Evolution is the thing that most commonly clashes with Christianity but even then there are many Christians who are not strict creationists and have no problem accepting scientific evidence. Likewise, there are non-Christians that refuse to accept things like vaccines and non-Christrians that accept all of the commonly-accepted theories within the scientific community. Of course even for people that reject certain things, that doesn’t actually mean they don’t believe in science. Science is a process. Disbelieving something commonly accepted in the scientific community isn’t a rejection of all science, it’s usually a belief that information or processes are flawed or have been misrepresented. It may be a misguided belief and I think many of them have been misled themselves, but it still doesn’t mean that the person doesn’t believe in science at all.

“To christians: If you believe in science, how can you also believe in The Bible? For example, science states that the earth is 2.5 billion years old, while The Bible states it is 4,000.” Like others have said, The bible doesn't state that the earth is 4000 years old. Also, science doesn't state that the earth is 2.5 billion years old. Some biblical scholars believe that there is enough evidence in the bible to believe that the earth is about 6000 years old. Some scientists believe that there is enough scientific evidence to believe that the earth is billions of years old. They now think it is about 4.4–4.5 billion years old. That number is constantly changing. A theory that the earth is old, is needed to support the theory of evolution. This is enough motivation to cause some people to make assumptions that compromise the theory. Scientific evidence that the earth is young is overlooked or disregarded because it doesn't aid the theory of evolution. If there was enough evidence to refute the theory of an old earth and support the theory of a young earth, the theory of evolution would have to be reworked or compleatly thrown out. This is simply unthinkable to many scientists. Scientists used to think that the earth was flat. Scientists used to think that the Earth was the center of the universe. Scientists have a long history of being wrong. There is nothing wrong with doubting scientists. To believe in science, is to believe in the scientific method. To believe in the bible, is to believe in God. There is no contradiction in believing in God and the scientific method. There is no scientific evidence that proves the earth is 4.5 billion years old. There is scientific evidence that is consistent with the theory of a 4.5 billion year old earth but there is also scientific evidence that is consistent with a young earth.

No, at least I do not believe in science. Science is a tool. A tool either works for me or it does not. There is nothing to “believe” about. Religion on the other hand is a type of mindset. About the unknown and maybe the un-knowable. The answer for the “why” questions. The ultimate why, not this “how does my fingernail grow out of my finger” kind of question. Nice to know and fun to share, but it will not mean a thing to me. For doctors it is another thing. So science explains the how. If I want to know, how the engine of my car works, I would need Science. If I want to know, why I we are here in the first place, I might go to a silent place by myself and hope for spiritual inspiration to give me some insights. Sometimes, consulting old scripture will do, or even getting together with likewise searching persons.

Yes, Christians believe in science. We believe science as well as all the other studies in humanity are true and accurate when they follow biblical principles. That does eliminate things like evolution…which even though it’s taught as fact doesn’t really have the science to back it up. It can’t be observed, tested, or repeated. Every species that “evolved” had to have a male and female evolve at the same rate and in complementary ways in order to reproduce. I find that truth hard to even speculate in an evolutionary process. Through the years and even today there are many scientists in the various fields who are sincere Christians. They’re a minority of course, but that’s true in every field.

As both a trained scientist and a trained Christian theologian, I can say this: sensible, thinking Christians certainly do. Sadly, many atheists and agnostics (and even some Christians) try to argue that science and Scripture are in conflict when in reality, they are separate disciplines, each with its own focus and methods. Science, by its own definition, concerns itself with the natural world—with what can be observed and measured. Theology’s focus is the supernatural—that is, everything that lies beyond the scope of science. To expect either discipline to effectively do the work of the other is illogical. Theology specifically studies what happens when God transcends the boundaries of human science, and science describes what happens in this observable world.

Huh?!? 4,000 years??? Land Sakes! No! It’s usually argued to be between 6,000 to 10,000 years. And besides, Science and the Bible do not contradict one another. The problem is not with “how we think,” because our cognitive skills work in the same way: We take raw data and input it into our headsWe analyze the data with the known algorithms we were taughtWe come to conclusions.The ONLY difference between someone who believes the Bible to be accurate and one who rejects the Bible are “presuppositions”. That’s it. Everything else, literally, everything else is the same. Those presuppositions are so effective, they radically alter the outcome. For instance, I spent some time in the Grand Canyon. It’s a beautiful place! When I go there, I see a lot on how the Great Flood impacted the landscape, produce the massive wash off to the West, and the deep cuts of the canyon. I can take professional scientific geologists (who are creationists) and they can show clear and scientific evidence of a flood. All of this is based on empirical evidence PLUS presuppositions. The other answers here already do a great job of covering almost all of the salient points thoroughly. One last one to add, and possibly the most controversial (although, in a purely intellectual world, it wouldn’t be). I can reject the conclusions drawn using foundational assumptions with which I disagree, without rejecting the science or the facts of a matter. Almost anything ‘scientific’ that deals with past events that cannot be repeated, must rely on assumptions about either the past events, the nature of the environment in which they occurred, or the nature of the environment that the physical evidence occupied in the intervening years. If even one assumption is incorrect, the conclusions that are then extrapolated from those foundational assumptions will end up diverging from the truth of what happened by an exponential order. The theory of evolution, radio-carbon dating calibration, etc are the best tools for explaining what we see IF we accept a number of foundational assumptions BEFORE we examine the evidence. Granted, many people that disagree with these things (evolution, extremely old dates, etc) are ignorant and biased. So are many of the people that agree with them. If I disagree with one or more of the foundational assumptions of a theory, I can disagree with the validity of that theory, without having to disagree with any scientifically established facts. The theory of evolution has some major problems. The theory of Creationism has some major problems. Ultimately, whichever one you choose to accept is going to most likely come down to which set of foundational assumptions you are most comfortable with. And both of them will require you to accept certain contradictions which they do a poor job of explaining. In closing, I believe that there is enough reason (not belief) to doubt either theory without requiring ignorance or a lack of rational thinking. That doesn’t prevent many people on both sides of the issue from employing no rational thinking whatsoever in considering the matter. These are simply my thoughts on this subject, I am not a scientist, but this stuff interests me. I tend to investigate things that interest me. I hope it is of some help to someone.
